segments.text: Could you please introduce yourself and describe your current occupation?
My name is John Dixon, Lieutenant Colonel, United States Army.
I'm an intelligence officer with 21 years in the service.
Could you describe the early part of your military career and how did you become interested in the field of military intelligence?
I was first commissioned in the infantry.
was not very pleased with the duty in the infantry.
It wasn't what I considered to be a challenge mentally.
It was very boring, I thought.
And I had extensive contact in my first assignment in Berlin with intelligence officers, neighbors, friends, and people that I dealt with on the staff in Berlin Brigade.
And after, I guess, two and a half years, I became convinced that I wanted to transfer to intelligence.
I did that in 1967 and then went for training at Fort Holabird, Maryland, where I became an aerial surveillance officer.
When were you stationed in Vietnam?
I arrived in Vietnam January 22, 1968, and stayed there exactly one year, departing in January of 1969.
Before you stationed in Vietnam, what type of special training did you see that prepared you for your intelligence gathering in the Vietnam theater?

When I arrived in Fort Holabird, Maryland in June of 1967, I went through a short course called the Intelligence Officers Orientation Course, which was designed to teach young officers the basics of tactical and combat intelligence.
This included things like collection management, analysis, the various disciplines of intelligence.
It really was very simply a vocabulary and a set of concepts that gave an officer an orientation.
It was tailored.
At this time, they had already started tailoring the course for Vietnam so that a lot of the stuff that we learned was designed to be used in Vietnam.
I then attended a six-month-long course designed to train aerial surveillance operators.
These officers basically are photo intelligence officers.
This course taught the basics of photography from an aerial viewpoint, the various kinds of imagery and collection to include infrared, airborne radar, side-looking airborne radar.
And it taught how these collectors could be exploited to find the enemy, identify the enemy, identify his activity.
We learned how to identify enemy equipment from aerial photography.
We learned how to plan aerial photography missions, how to debrief the flying crews, and how to produce the intelligence product that came from it.
This course was not yet
completely adapted to Vietnam.

Most of the collectors that we had, the sensors that we had in aerial surveillance at the time were oriented more towards conventional warfare and the course had not yet caught up with the sudden change in technology that was going on at that time in Vietnam.
So it really wasn't aimed at
collection in Vietnam, although we may have spent a week or so on its application.
It wasn't very applicable to Vietnam.
What type of duties did you perform while stationed in Vietnam?
When I first reported to Vietnam, because I had been an operations officer in the infantry, even though I was newly trained in intelligence, I was appointed assistant operations officer the first
Military Intelligence Battalion Aerial Reconnaissance and Surveillance.
This battalion was headquartered in Saigon, although it had detachments throughout Vietnam, from as far north as Da Nang down to the Delta in Can Tho, which is on the Mekong River.
The mission of the MIBARS, as the unit was called, was to provide aerial reconnaissance support to the field army by providing liaison
photographic products and intelligence reporting in conjunction with the Air Force who flew the majority of the aerial reconnaissance missions that we supported.
What type of tasks did you perform while working in your second job?
My second job was as intelligence officer or S2 of an infantry battalion.
in the 1st Infantry Division.
This was 2nd Battalion, 28th Infantry.
The intelligence officer for an infantry battalion doesn't do very sophisticated intelligence work.

The job there is to keep the commander informed as to the enemy activity in his area and in the areas adjacent to him, provide information to the commander on the terrain, on the weather, on known or suspected locations of enemy units,
and to support operations and operations planning so that the commander can effectively use his troops.

My job included coordination with higher headquarters to find out what intelligence picture they had, to try to find where they thought the enemy was, and this required constant flying back and forth to the headquarters.
I did a lot of reconnaissance on my own, briefed patrols, debriefed the patrols,

helped interrogate prisoners, flew scout missions myself, where we would hang out of the helicopter and try to find enemy tracks, enemy footprints in the mud, and that sort of thing, just in an effort to try to locate the enemy.
You arrived in Vietnam right before the Tet Offensive.
Did the military intelligence apparatus predict a New Year's Offensive by the Viet Cong and NVA?
If they had predicted the Viet Cong attack during Tet of 68, they didn't tell us about it because we had absolutely no forewarning.
The first thing that I recall knowing about the Tet Offensive was waking up the morning of the attack to gunfire.
And we were right in the midst of the NVA and Viet Cong regiments that had infiltrated into Saigon.
If anyone knew about it, they gave us no warning.
Now, I am told that units in the field that were closer to the intelligence picture out in the countryside saw something happening.
But whether or not they called it or not is the question.
And I don't believe most of them called an attack at that time.
They felt something was happening, but none of them saw the magnitude or the significance of the attack.

and the fact that the enemy would be able to get entire units into Saigon and conduct an attack that threatened the entire government and MacVie headquarters, Tan Son Nhat Air Base, and an attack that would really threaten and would involve just about everyone in Vietnam.
Almost every unit was involved in the Tet Offensive in Vietnam.
And I don't think anyone saw that coming.
You're saying that there was some hint in the tactical

military intelligence in the field that there was going to be an offensive but other operatives like the cia and other military intelligence gatherers were pretty much ignorant of the attack i don't think if anyone did know about it they they sure didn't pass the word around the uh i i had friends who were located at two field force headquarters and up in the first field force headquarters in the hill country in the mountains and have talked to them since and i have
found very, very few people who said they saw it coming.
Some folks in signals intelligence have said that they felt perhaps it was coming, and they had some indications.
Everyone had indications that units were moving and that something was afoot, but I don't think anybody realized exactly what was happening or realized the magnitude of the attack that was coming.
In other words, I think they were caught by surprise.
How did U.S. intelligence personnel overcome the initial unfamiliarity with the local environment and inexperience with the enemy?
Not very well.
One thing you've got to remember is that everybody there was there for one year, usually.
Now and then people would extend for more.
And you just don't build up intelligence, experience, expertise, knowledge of the environment
in that short period of time.

The change in culture, the change in physical environment, the unusual physical environment, the fact that the enemy was at home and we were not, just handicapped our intelligence collection immensely.
And as a result, we tended to rely more on technical collection devices, technology, rather than classical intelligence collection.
We just didn't have our grasp or have our finger on the human aspect of intelligence in Vietnam.
We didn't understand the Vietnamese and the way the Vietnamese thought.
We didn't understand the Orientals in general.
They were able to sell us a bill of goods quite frequently.
For example, it was not uncommon for an agent, a Vietnamese or a Chinese agent in the Delta, for example, to be selling intelligence
reports to five different intelligence collection agencies, sell the same report.
We had no collection management, no source control, so that he could get away with that.
And he could also manipulate us just to make money.
After the Tet Offensive, the big issue was when would the next offensive come?
And you could see very clear patterns when these intelligence entrepreneurs, these businessmen, would make money
selling reports of the next Tet Offensive, because they would flow, you'd start to see the reports, April of 68 is going to be the big attack, and nothing happened in April of 68.
And it was very clear that somebody was selling us a bill of goods.
These multiple sources, the inability of the Americans to handle Vietnamese and Chinese agents effectively caused the human aspect of intelligence to mislead us.
The technical
collection, aerial surveillance, signal surveillance, they could never be exactly perfect.
There's always going to be some ambiguity with them.
And so you had no way to corroborate what you got from your sensors with a good human intelligence report.
And combine that with the fact that the enemy was just very security conscious.
It made it difficult.
Are you suggesting that the intelligence officers and personnel should maybe have stayed in Vietnam and been
for longer than a year?
Any intelligence operation, in order for it to be effective, the operatives have to be there a long, long time.
Now, there were some there.
The CIA had people there for a long, long time.
And the Green Berets would have people that would volunteer for a long time.
But you're right.
The one-year tour hurt us to that extent.
It hurt us in other areas.
It hurt us in combat effectiveness and other things.
But it definitely hurt us in intelligence.
It takes you six months to learn your area, maybe two or three months of effective work, and then you were getting short, and by then it was time to leave.
Could you describe some of the high-tech devices you used to detect the enemy?
Well, when I first got there, we had a package of reconnaissance sensors that were pretty standard.
Aerial photography had become very sophisticated.
You had some high-speed cameras and panoramic
cameras and nose angle cameras in the aircraft that would give you extremely high and very, very good resolution.
Their biggest problem was the fact that they wouldn't penetrate the jungle.
And so we'd take miles and miles of film and have nice pictures of jungle and very high resolution, high quality imagery that wouldn't show us very much.
We had just introduced infrared, airborne infrared, into the collection package.
And this is mounted on
on either a small aircraft owned by the Army called a Mohawk, or it was mounted in a RF-101 owned by the Air Force, the Mohawk would find campfires with this infrared.
And that proved very effective in the early days because the Viet Cong at night would stop to rest, or during the day even, would stop to rest and cook their rice and cook their soup.

And when they didn't realize what was going on, when they first introduced the sensor to Vietnam, it was extremely effective because one mission could reveal an entire bivouac area for North Vietnamese regiment or Viet Cong regiment.
And very quickly, the American forces realized how they could and developed a system to capitalize on this intelligence by tying the reports in from the infrared with the artillery and bombing
planners, and we made good use of this reconnaissance.
But it didn't take long for the Viet Cong to realize that every time they lit a campfire, artillery would come in on them.
And so they started using all sorts of techniques to avoid the infrared.
For example, they would build a cover for a campfire that would diffuse the heat.
And what it would do would make it so that it wasn't nearly as great a heat source.
Or they would always build their campfires under deep jungle instead of building them
where there was any chance the heat might radiate out through the jungle.
And as a result of this, after a while, it became more and more difficult to find the enemy using infrared.
Side-looking airborne radar was introduced in the country.
It was originally designed to find tanks and armored personnel carriers and trucks.
It had a limitation.
in that it could find moving targets if they were going a minimum speed or had a minimum size.
But invariably, we were looking at individual soldiers running down a trail, and they were neither large enough nor fast enough to show up on side-looking airborne radar.
And so SLAR, as it was called, was used mainly along the borders looking into Cambodia and Laos and trying to find the Ho Chi Minh Trail and to try to peg
where the big supply trucks were moving, who apparently moved in large numbers with relative freedom over there along the trail.
And it was tough to find the Ho Chi Minh Trail without slar.
As long as you didn't have real thick canopy, slar could penetrate.
But about halfway through my tour, the Army and everyone started introducing what are called seismic intrusion devices.
And these are gadgets.
to feel the vibration of the earth as a soldier walks by or as a truck comes by.
And it would radio that sensing back to a central location.
And we had these seismic intrusion devices introduced into our area of operation in June or July of 1968.
And it proved very, very effective because the Vietnamese didn't know they were there.
They thought they were relatively free to run up and down the trail.
And what it would do was tell us that there is movement on a trail segment between point so-and-so and point so-and-so.
And it allowed us to establish a pattern of enemy movement.
And it allowed us to determine where ambushes would be effective and where artillery fire would be effective.
Did these technological devices replace the loss in human
intelligence factors, did they at all compensate for the loss of human?
I think they certainly made things a little bit better because without them it would have been a disaster.
The human intelligence collection was so ineffective.
At least it appeared to be from our point of view.
But I can tell you that at the tactical level, at the infantry battalion level, they were very effective for us because they really determined
where we were going to operate, and it was simple little things.
They protected us in many cases.
In June of 1968, they introduced these seismic intrusion devices to be used even by ambush patrols.

What would amount to it, an ambush would set up, and they could put these devices one up and down the trail on either side, and one out to the front and one to the rear, and the platoon leader, the lieutenant, or the sergeant there could tell if the enemy was coming
15 minutes before the enemy got there.
And that was providing him with warning that we never got before.
And it caused the enemy to be ambushed very effectively in a lot of cases, and it protected our patrols from counter-ambush where the enemy might figure out that our guys were there.
Our guys would know about it beforehand.
Another technical device that I failed to mention that was introduced at this time and about this time was the night observation device.
This is a device that enhances the existing light, no matter how dim it might be, so that you could see the enemy in almost pitch dark.
And before the introduction of this device, the night belonged to the enemy.
There was no doubt about it.
Our guys could never develop the night vision that was needed.
The Viet Cong would live in the dark.
North Vietnamese live in the dark for a year, trying to infiltrate down.
And so we could never win the night until the night observation device was introduced.
And these involved

They looked anything from a small scope that went on a rifle for sniper purposes up to a huge device about the size of a trombone or even larger that could be mounted on a tower and could collect light out two or three miles.

And this virtually took the night away from the enemy and gave us the ability to see movement out around our defensive positions for a mile or two in any direction so long as the observation was clear
The enemy could not surprise you with the night observation device.

And there were many cases where snipers, when they were first introduced, snipers could use these night observation devices with a silencer on their rifle to pick off the enemy, and the enemy wouldn't even know what was hitting them.
And the sniper would report the other enemy who were not shot with the first round would wonder what had happened.
They were running around confused because it couldn't tell
where the shot was coming from, and they couldn't imagine how anyone could see them to shoot them.
Did the defoliation efforts of the ranch hands aid you in your effort as an aerial reconnaissance officer, or did it simply drive the enemy from the defoliated areas?

I think it probably drove them from the defoliated area, but you've got to admit that that in itself aided us in our effort to find the enemy, because what it did was it took that part of the ground away from the enemy.
There were only a few large areas in our area of operation that had been totally defoliated.
By the time I was out in the field with the infantry battalion, much of the ground had already been plowed down with what were called Rome plows.
This is where you would take huge caterpillar tractors with chains in between them and just plow the jungle into the ground.
And that was massive defoliation of a non-chemical nature.
We had some defoliation in our area, and I recall flying over some of the scouting, never finding any enemy in the area.
And yet you could see evidence that before the defoliation, the area had been totally infiltrated with bunkers and trenches and foxholes.
I remember flying over a zigzag trench that had been dug through the jungle for, oh, I would say two or three miles, just like in World War I.
And I would guess that beforehand, and the trench was oriented so that troops could walk down the trench headed straight towards the large air base at Benoit.
And the best I can imagine was before defoliation under the triple canopy jungle, you could move a company through that trench.
And unless you put an artillery around right into the trench, they were safe the whole way.
Well, now with defoliation, the trench was useless because we knew where it was.

so my answer to that question is yes I think that it was effective and it helped us in our efforts to find the enemy but at the same time it did drive them to those areas that were not defoliated and it made us made it it helped us in that we knew where the enemy might be but it we just couldn't find them in the defoliated area once the area had been stripped away I think that before going further though I think I should say the Rome plow was much more important to us because the Rome plow opened up entire
made the jungle into a prairie.

So that at one point, for example, we had a tower built in our night defensive position, and I could see 10 miles in one direction with binoculars, and at night see 5 miles with that night observation device.
And no one could literally, no one could move through there in large numbers without us catching them because of the roll cloud.
Were you aware of the Phoenix program while you were stationed in Vietnam?
I was aware of the Phoenix program.
I didn't have a lot of contact with it.

And the way I was aware of it was that at one point I trained a lot of people who were on the Phoenix program as to how to use aerial reconnaissance, reconnaissance products, what reconnaissance could do for them.
My dealings were not very extensive with them.
They were not located in an area.
They did not operate in the areas that I was located in when I was with the infantry.
And as a result, I didn't have any operational dealings with them per se.
I remember one time bumping into one of the CIA guys that worked in that business.
He had some national police that came out with us and helped us on a sweep of the village.
But for the most part, I had very little dealings with them because they weren't operating in our area of operations.
Did you coordinate your intelligence efforts with other similar networks?
I would coordinate very closely with the local advisors and with the local, if there was an ARVIN unit in our area, I would on occasion go over and visit them.
But our situation was somewhat unique in that we were working in an area that had been declared a free-fire zone.
And what that meant was that all of the local civilians, for the most part, had been relocated out of the area so that we could assume that anybody in the area was in it.
And that was the basic rule.
If you were out there, you were a target.
And for that reason, we didn't have too many other agencies to coordinate with.
It was our area of operation, just very much like an isolated little war of its own.
Did you feel that the lack of coordination with ARVIN or not using ARVIN as interpreters kind of was a liability to your intelligence gathering?
I think it could have hurt us.
It would have helped us if we could have, for example, had an infantry company of all ARVN with us in the infantry battalion that we were in.
But that didn't happen.
We did have ARVN soldiers to serve as our interpreters within the infantry battalion.
I had three interpreters that were assigned to me all the time.
and they were designed to help us interrogate prisoners on the spot.
You see, when you capture a prisoner, the most effective interrogation happens right after the capture.

When the soldier, when the enemy is scared, he doesn't know what's going to happen, he's still frightened from the battle and disoriented, and he hasn't had a chance to talk to any of his leaders that are also captured.
And also, you can get information from him at that time that can help you in the immediate fight that you're still in.
And so I had three ARVN interpreters that were with me that spoke pretty good English.
And they were with us full time.
And I would send them out with the rifle companies in case a capture took place.
And their job was to find out what was going on.
And they would answer to the immediate company commander that was there.
They were somewhat of a problem because they tended to try to avoid combat.
They didn't want to get shot at.
And there were even times when at least one of them I suspected as being a BC sympathizer because he tended to disappear right before the big fights.
He would always have to go back to base camp to check on his finance or his pay or something just before we got our 9th defensive position attack and that sort of thing.
I never was able to pin anything on him, but he was a relatively unreliable sort of character that...
became a liability.
One of them was very good, and I could use him to get out there when we captured somebody and get immediate information that the company commander or the battalion commander could use.
But I think ideally we should have had perhaps ARVN soldiers with us, particularly if we were operating in an area where there were civilian population also alongside us.
But
In our area of operation, as I said, there weren't very many civilians.
And as a result, I'm not so sure that we would have used that capability.
What we might could have used is someone who knew the area better, the terrain, knew where the creek bottoms were, knew where the trails were.
And that's what we really lacked.
We didn't know the ground very well.
And it's just a complex terrain that could be very confusing.
And the enemy knew it better than us.
And as a result, we're able to use it better.
What type of warfare would you classify the conflict that you were participating in?

Well, at the time that I was the S2 of 2nd Battalion, 28th Infantry, our battle, our tactic had to be one that was almost conventional warfare, in that we were located northeast of Saigon, about 40, 50 miles out, and our job was to deny the enemy
infiltration into the capital area so that they could not mass for the follow-up offensive to the Tet Offensive of 1968.
Generally, I think the authorities, the people in country that did this sort of thing thought that the enemy would mount another offensive in May.
They tried to mount a small offensive, but they really weren't capable, and they thought another Tet was coming maybe in the fall.
And so our mission was to get out and
deny infiltration.
And it turned out that really we were ambushing in company size almost, not little small ambushes.
And we were trying to find the enemy out at the 40 mile range out there so that we could engage them before they could assemble and move south.
We were working against organized units, conventional units, not small change outfits.
There were times when our ambushes would pop on
on 50-man units moving through the jungle, certainly not classical guerrilla-type warfare.
The units that we fought against were armed with machine guns, mortars, anti-tank rocket launchers, and therefore couldn't be considered to be guerrilla-type organizations.
They had sergeants and captains and colonels in charge.
They had communications.
They were mainline North Vietnamese units
or they were Viet Cong units that were trained along the same organization line.
After serving in Vietnam, you attended several professional military schools.
How was the topic of Vietnam treated?
Well, in fact, after Vietnam, I returned to Fort Holabird and for one year attended what's called the Intelligence Officers Advance Course.
The course was one of those experiences that you have now and then where it's just beyond reality how inapplicable that course was for our development.
It was sort of a hodgepodge, an effort to try to prepare officers to go to Vietnam, in case anyone hadn't, although all of us had already been to Vietnam once.
And yet it was an effort to continue to try to watch for the Soviets in the European theater.
and how to be an intelligence officer against them.
Very, very few of the experiences in Vietnam were taught in this officer's advance course.
They hadn't been condensed, consolidated.
They had not been put into doctrine yet.
And I don't think anybody was.
I think we were fighting a war at the time, and therefore didn't have time to sit back and think about how to do it better.
That's unfortunate.
We probably should have.
Eight years later, I went to the Command and General Staff College in Fort Leavenworth, Kansas.
And there, after that period of time, you would have thought that someone would have sat down and thought this out.
Vietnam had fallen by then.
This was 1976.
And I think that I would have thought that people would have had plenty of opportunity to review the subject and to come up with at least some lessons learned
that could be taught, if not an entire new concept or doctrine for this sort of warfare.

But instead, what I found was that the Army had turned to the east, to the European theater, to conventional war against the Soviets, and was concentrating its efforts on learning the Soviet warfare techniques and equipment and organization better, and totally ignored
counter-revolutionary warfare, counter-guerrilla warfare, low-intensity warfare, whatever you might want to call it.
There were a couple of electives offered in the subject.
I'm told that they offered very little in new ideas.
We rarely talked about Vietnam unless someone was telling war stories, and everything that we were doing and everything that we learned was oriented towards the
towards the European environment and totally ignored the Vietnamese experience.
That contrasted, however, to the British Army Staff College.
In 1980, I attended the British Army Staff College and was one of three Americans there.
I found that the Brits concentrated on this sort of warfare.
They called it
counter-revolutionary warfare for almost one-third of the year-long course.

It's a little wonder because the Brits are still involved in this sort of situation or conflict in Northern Ireland and they're spending a lot of effort to it and perhaps they're doing it right because their tactics are a little bit more clearly resolved than ours.
They use low-level
They seem to use intelligence better.
They don't rely so heavily on technology as we do, although the technology has got its part with the British effort.
But in general, it was just somewhat surprising to see that they spend more effort and more time teaching their officers how to do this sort of warfare than we do.
Perhaps we'll get back to that someday.
But we haven't done it yet that I know of.

and repeatedly I've asked general officers in our army when that's going to happen and it doesn't seem as though it's come back into vogue yet and won't be until perhaps we have another environment, another threat to us in that sort of situation that we're required.
Do you think that the military intelligence community is prepared for
a similar situation, let's say, in Central America?
Are they prepared to assess the level of conflict and predict the enemy's troop movements, et cetera?
I think we're better off now.
And that sort of contradicts what I said before.
But I'll tell you why.
And it's a simplistic response, maybe, but I think it has some weight of truth.
And that is that the Central American environment
We're more familiar with it.
We have more people that speak that language.
We know better how the people there think.
We have a better assessment of their techniques.
We know the environment there.
We know the terrain.
We know the national conditions that exist, although we don't handle it very smart, at least at the strategic level, perhaps.
I think we're better prepared for...
a similar situation in Central America.
And I think we would do much better.
The Oriental mystique, the failure of Americans to even understand how an Oriental thinks was perhaps our fundamental cause of our downfall in Vietnam.
And we just didn't know how to think in their terms.
I think we know how to think perhaps a little bit better in a Latin American term.
I think we've had more contact with them.
We have, for example, the Army has about 10% of its people who speak Spanish as their first language.
And that reason alone will help us.
That fact alone helps us a lot.
The fact that we've had a greater presence in Latin America over history and a greater knowledge of what goes on down there will help us a lot, I believe.
But at the same time,

If we make the same mistakes in Latin America that we made in Vietnam concerning our assessment of the so-called enemies, will our assessment of the enemy's determination or their capability to conduct extended protracted warfare, if we make those same mistakes and we go about it in the wrong way as we did in Vietnam, we're not going to come out any better.
We've got to look at the strategic situation
carefully before we make any commitments there.
And that strategic situation and decision will then determine how we do things at the grassroots level.
